metadata.description: Comprehensive test data for legal knowledge graph schema testing
test_scenarios: Complex relationships (single case with multiple connections)
Edge cases (overruled then reinstated, conflicting precedents, superseded statutes)

cases.title: Kesavananda Bharati v. State of Kerala
cases.summary: Established the Basic Structure Doctrine - Parliament cannot amend the Constitution so as to alter its basic structure.
cases.headnotes: Constitutional Law - Amendment - Limits - Basic Structure Doctrine established

cases.title: Anwar Hossain Chowdhury v. Bangladesh
cases.summary: Adopted the Basic Structure Doctrine from India. Eighth Amendment unconstitutional as it violates basic structure.
cases.headnotes: Constitutional Law - Basic Structure Doctrine applied in Bangladesh

cases.title: Government of Bangladesh v. Professor Nurul Islam
cases.summary: Reaffirmed Basic Structure Doctrine. Fifth Amendment unconstitutional.
cases.headnotes: Constitutional Law - Basic Structure - Validation of Martial Law orders

cases.title: State v. Abdul Rahman
cases.summary: Conviction under Section 302 Penal Code upheld. Right to fair trial under Article 32 Constitution analyzed.
cases.headnotes: Criminal Law - Murder - Section 302 Penal Code - Constitutional right to fair trial

cases.title: AK Gopalan v. State of Madras
cases.summary: Narrow interpretation of Article 21. Later overruled by Maneka Gandhi.
cases.headnotes: Constitutional Law - Article 21 - Right to Life and Personal Liberty - Narrow interpretation

cases.title: Maneka Gandhi v. Union of India
cases.summary: Expanded interpretation of Article 21. Overruled AK Gopalan. Procedure must be fair, just and reasonable.
cases.headnotes: Constitutional Law - Article 21 - Right to Life includes right to live with dignity - Procedural safeguards

cases.title: Karim v. State
cases.summary: Applied procedural safeguards from Maneka Gandhi in bail hearing. Cited Indian precedent.
cases.headnotes: Criminal Procedure - Bail - Fair procedure requirements

cases.title: State v. Hossain
cases.summary: Conviction under Section 376 Penal Code. Later overruled by 2024 case on evidence standards.
cases.headnotes: Criminal Law - Rape - Section 376 - Evidence standards

cases.title: State v. Alam
cases.summary: Overruled Hossain. Stricter evidence standards required for rape convictions under Section 376.
cases.headnotes: Criminal Law - Rape - Section 376 - Enhanced evidence standards - Overruling precedent

cases.title: State v. Khan
cases.summary: Reinstated Hossain standards. Alam overruled. Balanced approach to evidence in rape cases.
cases.headnotes: Criminal Law - Rape - Evidence standards - Reinstating earlier precedent

cases.title: State of Karnataka v. Ravi
cases.summary: Murder conviction under Section 302 IPC. Death penalty commuted to life imprisonment.
cases.headnotes: Criminal Law - Murder - Section 302 IPC - Death penalty - Mitigating circumstances

cases.title: Federation of Pakistan v. Ahmad
cases.summary: Applied Basic Structure Doctrine from Indian jurisprudence to Pakistani Constitution.
cases.headnotes: Constitutional Law - Basic Structure - Cross-jurisdiction application

cases.title: Begum v. City Corporation
cases.summary: Property dispute. Applied ejusdem generis principle of statutory interpretation.
cases.headnotes: Property Law - Statutory Interpretation - Ejusdem Generis

cases.title: Union of India v. Sharma Industries
cases.summary: GST Act interpretation. Section 15 analyzed. Liberal interpretation favoring taxpayer.

cases.title: Rahman Traders v. NBR
cases.summary: VAT Act 1991, Section 25 interpretation. Followed liberal interpretation from Indian GST cases.
cases.headnotes: Tax Law - VAT - Section 25 - Liberal interpretation

statutes.name: Penal Code, 1860
statutes.summary: Original version of the Penal Code applicable in Bangladesh (inherited from British India)

statutes.name: Penal Code, 1860 (as amended 2000)
statutes.summary: First amendment - Enhanced penalties for violence against women

statutes.name: Penal Code, 1860 (as amended 2013)
statutes.summary: Second amendment - Changes to rape provisions (Section 376)

statutes.name: Penal Code, 1860 (as amended 2020)
statutes.summary: Current version - Death penalty for rape, cybercrime provisions added

statutes.name: Constitution of the People's Republic of Bangladesh, 1972
statutes.preamble: We, the people of Bangladesh... do hereby adopt, enact and give to ourselves this Constitution.

statutes.name: Constitution of India, 1950
statutes.preamble: We, the people of India... do hereby adopt, enact and give to ourselves this Constitution.

statutes.name: Central Goods and Services Tax Act, 2017
Value Added Tax Act, 1991
statutes.summary: Value Added Tax legislation for Bangladesh

sections.title: Punishment for murder
sections.text: Whoever commits murder shall be punished with death or transportation for life, and shall also be liable to fine.

sections.title: Punishment for murder
sections.text: Whoever commits murder shall be punished with death or imprisonment for life, and shall also be liable to fine.

sections.title: Punishment for rape
sections.text: Whoever commits rape shall be punished with imprisonment for life or for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

sections.title: Punishment for rape
sections.text: Whoever commits rape shall be punished with imprisonment for life or rigorous imprisonment for a term which shall not be less than ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

sections.title: Punishment for rape
sections.text: Whoever commits rape shall be punished with imprisonment for life or rigorous imprisonment for a term which shall not be less than ten years and may extend to twenty years, and shall also be liable to fine.

sections.title: Punishment for rape
sections.text: Whoever commits rape shall be punished with death or imprisonment for life, and shall also be liable to fine.

sections.title: Right to Life and Personal Liberty
sections.text: No person shall be deprived of life or personal liberty save in accordance with law.
sections.summary: Fundamental right to life and liberty

sections.title: Protection of life and personal liberty
sections.text: No person shall be deprived of his life or personal liberty except according to procedure established by law.
sections.summary: Fundamental right to life and personal liberty in India

sections.title: Punishment for murder
sections.text: Whoever commits murder shall be punished with death, or imprisonment for life, and shall also be liable to fine.

sections.title: Value of taxable supply
sections.text: The value of a supply of goods or services or both shall be the transaction value, which is the price actually paid or payable for the said supply of goods or services or both...
sections.summary: Determination of taxable value under GST

sections.title: Tax deduction at source
sections.text: The Government may, by notification in the official Gazette, direct any person making payment to any registered person to deduct tax at such rate as may be specified...
sections.summary: Provisions for tax deduction at source under VAT

judges.name: Justice ABM Khairul Haque
judges.biography: Presided over the Eighth Amendment Case (1989)

judges.name: Justice S.M. Sikri
judges.biography: Chief Justice during Kesavananda Bharati case

legal_principles.name: Basic Structure Doctrine
legal_principles.definition: Parliament cannot amend the Constitution so as to alter its basic structure. Certain features of the Constitution are beyond the amending power of Parliament.
legal_principles.description: The Basic Structure Doctrine holds that the Constitution has certain basic features that cannot be altered or destroyed through amendments. These include supremacy of the Constitution, rule of law, independence of judiciary, secularism, federalism, and separation of powers.

legal_principles.name: Ejusdem Generis
legal_principles.definition: Where general words follow specific words in a statute, the general words must be confined to things of the same kind as those specified.
legal_principles.description: Rule of statutory interpretation: when a list of specific items is followed by general words, the general words are interpreted to be limited to items of the same type as the specific items.

legal_principles.name: No one can be a judge in their own cause
legal_principles.definition: No person can judge a case in which they have an interest.
legal_principles.description: Fundamental principle of natural justice - a decision-maker must be impartial and unbiased. Anyone with a personal interest in the outcome must recuse themselves.

legal_principles.name: Right to be heard
legal_principles.definition: No one should be condemned unheard. Every person has the right to be heard before an adverse decision is made.
legal_principles.description: Fundamental principle of natural justice - before making a decision affecting someone's rights, they must be given notice and an opportunity to present their case.

legal_issues.description: Whether the Constitution has a basic structure that cannot be amended by Parliament
What is the scope and meaning of 'personal liberty' under Article 21/32
What are the essential elements of murder under Section 302
What standard of evidence is required for conviction in rape cases
Whether fair trial guarantees under Article 32 apply to bail hearings
How should 'transaction value' be determined under Section 15 GST Act
Application of ejusdem generis in property title disputes

CITES.context: Adopted the Basic Structure Doctrine from Kesavananda Bharati
Reaffirmed Basic Structure Doctrine established in Eighth Amendment Case
Applied Basic Structure principles from Kesavananda Bharati
Expressly overruled the narrow interpretation of Article 21 in AK Gopalan
Applied procedural safeguards from Maneka Gandhi to bail proceedings
Discussed constitutional right to fair trial
Analyzed procedural fairness requirements in criminal trials
Expressly overruled Hossain - stricter evidence standards required
Reinstated the balanced evidence standards from Hossain
Considered Indian precedent on Section 302 sentencing principles
Applied Basic Structure Doctrine to Pakistani Constitution
Noted Bangladesh's adoption of Basic Structure Doctrine
Applied liberal interpretation principles from Indian GST case to VAT provisions

INTERPRETS.holding: Constitution has a basic structure that cannot be amended
Bangladesh Constitution has a basic structure following Indian precedent
All elements of murder must be proved beyond reasonable doubt
Article 32 includes right to fair trial with procedural safeguards
Article 21 only requires procedure established by law, not fairness
Article 21 requires procedure to be fair, just and reasonable, not merely lawful
Victim's testimony alone sufficient for conviction if credible
Corroboration required; victim's testimony alone insufficient
Victim's testimony primary evidence but must be scrutinized carefully; corroboration preferred but not mandatory
Transaction value should be interpreted broadly in favor of taxpayer
Tax deduction provisions should be construed liberally favoring taxpayer

AMENDS.description: Enhanced penalties for violence against women
Introduced death penalty for rape, added cybercrime provisions
Introduced death penalty as punishment option

ADDRESSES.holding: Constitution has basic structure that cannot be amended
ADDRESSES.ratio_decidendi: While Parliament has wide amendment powers, it cannot destroy the basic structure of the Constitution

ADDRESSES.holding: Bangladesh Constitution has basic structure following Indian precedent
ADDRESSES.ratio_decidendi: Basic Structure Doctrine applies to Bangladesh Constitution

ADDRESSES.holding: Article 21 protects personal liberty from actions not sanctioned by law
ADDRESSES.ratio_decidendi: Narrow interpretation - procedure need only be established by law

ADDRESSES.holding: Article 21 includes right to live with dignity; procedure must be fair, just and reasonable
ADDRESSES.ratio_decidendi: Expanded interpretation - procedure must meet principles of natural justice

ADDRESSES.holding: All elements of murder under Section 302 proved beyond reasonable doubt
ADDRESSES.ratio_decidendi: Conviction upheld based on evidence of intention and act causing death

ADDRESSES.holding: Fair trial guarantees apply at all stages including investigation and trial
ADDRESSES.ratio_decidendi: Article 32 requires procedural fairness throughout criminal process

ADDRESSES.holding: Victim's testimony alone sufficient if credible
ADDRESSES.ratio_decidendi: Sexual offenses often occur in private; corroboration not mandatory
Given severity of punishment, stricter evidence standards necessary

ADDRESSES.holding: Victim's testimony primary evidence; corroboration preferred but not mandatory
ADDRESSES.ratio_decidendi: Balance between protecting victims and ensuring fair trials

ADDRESSES.holding: Transaction value is actual price paid or payable
ADDRESSES.ratio_decidendi: Tax provisions should be construed strictly; ambiguity resolved in favor of taxpayer

ADDRESSES.holding: Ejusdem generis applied to limit general words to same category as specific items
ADDRESSES.ratio_decidendi: Statutory interpretation requires reading statute as a whole

APPLIES.context: First case to establish the Basic Structure Doctrine
Applied Basic Structure Doctrine to Bangladesh Constitution
Reaffirmed and applied Basic Structure Doctrine
Applied Basic Structure Doctrine to Pakistan Constitution
Applied right to be heard as fundamental to Article 21
Applied right to be heard in bail proceedings
Applied ejusdem generis principle to interpret property statute
